review.title: Dynamic Bayesian Networks to simulate occupant behaviours in office buildings related to indoor air quality
review.abstract: This paper proposes a new general approach based on Bayesian networks to model the human behaviour. This approach represents human behaviour with probabilistic cause-effect relations based on knowledge, but also with conditional probabilities coming either from knowledge or deduced from observations. This approach has been applied to the co-simulation of the CO2 concentration in an office coupled with human behaviour.

sections.heading: INTRODUCTION
sections.text: Most of the world's building standards take into account the occupants through representative values and deterministic scenarios: number of occupants, predefined timetables and responses to a threshold exceeded. However, in buildings with low consumption, the influence of occupants "behaviour due to its influence on energy consumption and indoor climate through interactions with building physics becomes a determining consumption factor. Therefore, it is important to take into account the behaviour of occupants when estimating energy consumption. For example, if the air quality is poor, occupants may decide to open windows or doors depending on the type of windows, but also on the activities or wishes of other occupants. A high-performance building should be efficient for a wide variety of uses.

sections.heading: STATE OF THE ART
sections.text: In the scientific community of building physics, there is a growing interest in the behavior of residents due to their importance in reducing energy waste in buildings (Andersen et al, 2009).Residents "behavior can be studied from building physics to human biology, through sociology and psychology, to describe thermal, visual, and indoor air quality. In the literature, three types of approaches can be found: deterministic approaches based on predefined scenarios and behavioral rules; statistical approaches based on factual observations, such as surveys; and social modeling approaches that model cognitive and considered behavior patterns.
